L1 Product Generation Specification</gco:CharacterString></gmd:name><gmd:function><gmd:CI_OnLineFunctionCode codeList=\"http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_OnLineFunctionCode\" codeListValue=\"information\"/></gmd:function></gmd:CI_OnlineResource></gmd:onlineResource></gmd:CI_Contact></gmd:contactInfo><gmd:role><gmd:CI_RoleCode codeList=\"http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_RoleCode\" codeListValue=\"author\"/></gmd:role></gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty></gmd:citedResponsibleParty><gmd:citedResponsibleParty><gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty><gmd:contactInfo><gmd:CI_Contact><gmd:onlineResource><gmd:CI_OnlineResource><gmd:linkage><gmd:URL>https://www.eumetsat.int/media/38675</gmd:URL></gmd:linkage><gmd:name><gco:CharacterString>AVHRR 3 Level 1 Product Format Specification</gco:CharacterString></gmd:name><gmd:function><gmd:CI_OnLineFunctionCode codeList=\"http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_OnLineFunctionCode\" codeListValue=\"information\"/></gmd:function></gmd:CI_OnlineResource></gmd:onlineResource></gmd:CI_Contact></gmd:contactInfo><gmd:role><gmd:CI_RoleCode codeList=\"http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_RoleCode\" codeListValue=\"author\"/></gmd:role></gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty></gmd:citedResponsibleParty></gmd:CI_Citation></gmd:citation><gmd:abstract><gco:CharacterString>This is an RGB (Red, Green, Blue) composite image based upon data from solar and infrared channels from Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer/3 (AVHRR/3). The images are a combination of two AVHRR RGB composite products: the Natural Colour (daytime product based on solar channels) and Night Microphysics (i.e. Fog) product (based upon infrared channels, tuned for night-time conditions). \nThe product displays images composed of the last six AVHRR orbits, using the Natural Colour product in the daytime part and the Fog product in the night-time part. The indicated time represents the end of the last orbit (when the satellite crosses the equator in the ascending node). \nNatural Colour RGB images are created by combining data from three solar channels: 1.6 µm channel (NIR1.61, visualized in red), 0.87 µm channel (NIR0.87, visualized in green) and 0.63 µm channel (VIS0.63, visualized in blue). Its purpose is to supply general cloud analysis, by providing information on cloud top phase and cloud optical thickness in cloudy areas, and on the green vegetation fraction ('chlorophyll content') in cloud-free areas. In most cases, water clouds can be distinguished from ice clouds. Snow-covered land is easy to distinguish from snow-free land and from water clouds and fog. The colours are (relatively) close to the natural colours of the depicted features. \nThe Night Microphysics RGB (i.e. RGB Fog) images are created by combining data from the 12.0, 10.8 and 3.74 µm channels (IR12.0, IR10.8 and IR3.74 respectively). Brightness temperature differences are displayed in red (IR12.0- IR10.8) and green (IR12.0- IR3.9), while the IR10.8 channel is shown in blue beam. Its main purpose is to distinguish fog and low clouds from cloud-free areas at night, but it contains also information on cloud top temperature, cloud optical thickness and cloud top phase, thus revealing other cloud types. Cloud-free areas contain information on low-level moisture and surface temperature. \nThe Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer/3 (AVHRR/3) is a multipurpose imaging instrument used for global monitoring of cloud cover, sea surface temperature, ice, snow and vegetation cover characteristics. It operates at six different channels simultaneously at a spatial resolution of about 1 Km near-nadir. AVHRR has many applications in oceanography, meteorology and terrestrial sciences.</gco:CharacterString></gmd:abstract><gmd:status><gmd:MD_ProgressCode codeList=\"http://navigator.eumetsat.int/metadata_schema/eum/resources/Codelist/eum_gmxCodelists.xml#MD_ProgressCode\" id=\"z270aaa\" uuid=\"z270aaa\"/></gmi:type><eum:type><MI_EUMSensorTypeCode xmlns=\"http://www.eumetsat.int/2008/gmi\" codeList=\"http://navigator.eumetsat.int/metadata_schema/eum/resources/Codelist/eum_gmxCodelists.xml#CI_SensorTypeCode\" codeListValue=\"Radiometer\"/></eum:type></eum:MI_EUMInstrument></gmi:instrument><eum:orbitType><CI_OrbitTypeCode xmlns=\"http://www.eumetsat.int/2008/gmi\" codeList=\"http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_OrbitTypeCode\" codeListValue=\"LEO\"/></eum:orbitType></eum:MI_EUMPlatform></gmi:platform></gmi:MI_AcquisitionInformation></gmi:acquisitionInformation></gmi:MI_Metadata>"
#> 
#> $hits$hits[[8]]$`_source`$schemaOrgDefinition
#> [1] "{\"@context\":\"http://schema.org/\",\"@type\":\"Dataset\",\"url\":\"https://navigator.eumetsat.int/product/EO:EUM:DAT:0191\",\"measurementTechnique\":\"Radiometer\",\"copyrightHolder\":{\"@type\":\"Organization\",\"name\":\"EUMETSAT\",\"contactPoint\":{\"@type\":\"ContactPoint\",\"contactType\":\"customer support\",\"telephone\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3660/3770\",\"email\":\"ops@eumetsat.int\",\"url\":\"http://www.eumetsat.int\",\"faxNumber\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3790\"}},\"creator\":{\"@type\":\"Organization\",\"name\":\"EUMETSAT\",\"contactPoint\":{\"@type\":\"ContactPoint\",\"contactType\":\"customer support\",\"telephone\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3660/3770\",\"email\":\"ops@eumetsat.int\",\"url\":\"http://www.eumetsat.int\",\"faxNumber\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3790\"}},\"isAccessibleForFree\":\"false\",\"keywords\":\"Metop,GeoTIFF,Atmosphere,LEO,Cloud,Land,Radiometer,AVHRR\",\"license\":\"https://eoportal.eumetsat.int/userMgmt/terms.faces\",\"publisher\":{\"@type\":\"Organization\",\"name\":\"EUMETSAT\",\"contactPoint\":{\"@type\":\"ContactPoint\",\"contactType\":\"customer support\",\"telephone\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3660/3770\",\"email\":\"ops@eumetsat.int\",\"url\":\"http://www.eumetsat.int\",\"faxNumber\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3790\"}},\"schemaVersion\":\"3.5\",\"spatialCoverage\":{\"@type\":\"Place\",\"geo\":{\"@type\":\"GeoShape\",\"polygon\":\"-180.0  90.0  180.0  -90.0\"}},\"thumbnailUrl\":\"https://navigator.eumetsat.int/preview/eps-metop1_natural_fog_THUMBNAIL_small.jpg\",\"encodingFormat\":\"GeoTIFF\",\"description\":\"This is an RGB (Red, Green, Blue) composite image based upon data from solar and infrared channels from Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer/3 (AVHRR/3). The images are a combination of two AVHRR RGB composite products: the Natural Colour (daytime product based on solar channels) and Night Microphysics (i.e. Fog) product (based upon infrared channels, tuned for night-time conditions). \\nThe product displays images composed of the last six AVHRR orbits, using the Natural Colour product in the daytime part and the Fog product in the night-time part. The indicated time represents the end of the last orbit (when the satellite crosses the equator in the ascending node). \\nNatural Colour RGB images are created by combining data from three solar channels: 1.6 µm channel (NIR1.61, visualized in red), 0.87 µm channel (NIR0.87, visualized in green) and 0.63 µm channel (VIS0.63, visualized in blue). Its purpose is to supply general cloud analysis, by providing information on cloud top phase and cloud optical thickness in cloudy areas, and on the green vegetation fraction ('chlorophyll content') in cloud-free areas. In most cases, water clouds can be distinguished from ice clouds. Snow-covered land is easy to distinguish from snow-free land and from water clouds and fog. The colours are (relatively) close to the natural colours of the depicted features. \\nThe Night Microphysics RGB (i.e. RGB Fog) images are created by combining data from the 12.0, 10.8 and 3.74 µm channels (IR12.0, IR10.8 and IR3.74 respectively). Brightness temperature differences are displayed in red (IR12.0- IR10.8) and green (IR12.0- IR3.9), while the IR10.8 channel is shown in blue beam. Its main purpose is to distinguish fog and low clouds from cloud-free areas at night, but it contains also information on cloud top temperature, cloud optical thickness and cloud top phase, thus revealing other cloud types. Cloud-free areas contain information on low-level moisture and surface temperature. \\nThe Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer/3 (AVHRR/3) is a multipurpose imaging instrument used for global monitoring of cloud cover, sea surface temperature, ice, snow and vegetation cover characteristics. It operates at six different channels simultaneously at a spatial resolution of about 1 Km near-nadir. AVHRR has many applications in oceanography, meteorology and terrestrial sciences.\",\"identifier\":\"EO:EUM:DAT:0191\",\"name\":\"AVHRR RGB Natural Colour + Fog 6 orbits accumulated - Metop B\"}"
#>

#> [1] 1
#> 
#> $hits$hits[[9]]$`_source`
#> $hits$hits[[9]]$`_source`$abstract
#> [1] "This product is an RGB (Red, Green, Blue) composite based upon data from S3B single swath OLCI L1 NRT products Top-Of-Atmosphere (TOA) radiometric measurements, radiometrically corrected, calibrated and spectrally characterised. The product is composed from data from a combination of the following OLCI bands: 0a02_radiance, Oa06_radiance, Oa08_radiance. The images are generated with a pixel resolution of 0.09 degrees.\n'Ocean colour' is the change in the colour of the ocean, and other water bodies such as lakes, due to the substances dissolved and particles suspended within the water. The primary objective of OLCI products is to measure the colour of the ocean and land surface and provide information on ocean and land characteristics related to this (e.g. biology). OLCI also provides information on the atmosphere and contributes to climate studies. Sentinel-3 is part of a series of Sentinel satellites, under the umbrella of the EU Copernicus programme."

The product is composed from data from a combination of the following OLCI bands: 0a02_radiance, Oa06_radiance, Oa08_radiance. The images are generated with a pixel resolution of 0.09 degrees. 'Ocean colour' is the change in the colour of the ocean, and other water bodies such as lakes, due to the substances dissolved and particles suspended within the water. The primary objective of OLCI products is to measure the colour of the ocean and land surface and provide information on ocean and land characteristics related to this (e.g. biology). OLCI also provides information on the atmosphere and contributes to climate studies. Documents (ATBD etc)</gco:CharacterString></gmd:name><gmd:function><gmd:CI_OnLineFunctionCode codeList=\"http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_OnLineFunctionCode\" codeListValue=\"information\"/></gmd:function></gmd:CI_OnlineResource></gmd:onlineResource></gmd:CI_Contact></gmd:contactInfo><gmd:role><gmd:CI_RoleCode codeList=\"http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_RoleCode\" codeListValue=\"author\"/></gmd:role></gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty></gmd:citedResponsibleParty></gmd:CI_Citation></gmd:citation><gmd:abstract><gco:CharacterString>This product is an RGB (Red, Green, Blue) composite based upon data from S3B single swath OLCI L1 NRT products Top-Of-Atmosphere (TOA) radiometric measurements, radiometrically corrected, calibrated and spectrally characterised. The product is composed from data from a combination of the following OLCI bands: 0a02_radiance, Oa06_radiance, Oa08_radiance. The images are generated with a pixel resolution of 0.09 degrees.\n'Ocean colour' is the change in the colour of the ocean, and other water bodies such as lakes, due to the substances dissolved and particles suspended within the water. The primary objective of OLCI products is to measure the colour of the ocean and land surface and provide information on ocean and land characteristics related to this (e.g. biology). OLCI also provides information on the atmosphere and contributes to climate studies. Sentinel-3 is part of a series of Sentinel satellites, under the umbrella of the EU Copernicus programme.</gco:CharacterString></gmd:abstract><gmd:status><gmd:MD_ProgressCode codeList=\"http://navigator.eumetsat.int/metadata_schema/eum/resources/Codelist/eum_gmxCodelists.xml#MD_ProgressCode\" #> $hits$hits[[9]]$`_source`$schemaOrgDefinition
#> [1] "{\"@context\":\"http://schema.org/\",\"@type\":\"Dataset\",\"url\":\"https://navigator.eumetsat.int/product/EO:EUM:DAT:0182\",\"measurementTechnique\":\"Optical\",\"copyrightHolder\":{\"@type\":\"Organization\",\"name\":\"EUMETSAT for Copernicus\",\"contactPoint\":{\"@type\":\"ContactPoint\",\"contactType\":\"customer support\",\"telephone\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3660/3770\",\"email\":\"ops@eumetsat.int\",\"url\":\"http://www.eumetsat.int\",\"faxNumber\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3790\"}},\"creator\":{\"@type\":\"Organization\",\"name\":\"EUMETSAT for Copernicus\",\"contactPoint\":{\"@type\":\"ContactPoint\",\"contactType\":\"customer support\",\"telephone\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3660/3770\",\"email\":\"ops@eumetsat.int\",\"url\":\"http://www.eumetsat.int\",\"faxNumber\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3790\"}},\"isAccessibleForFree\":\"false\",\"keywords\":\"GeoTIFF,Sentinel-3,Atmosphere,Optical,OLCI,LEO,Cloud,Ocean,Level 1 Data,Land\",\"license\":\"https://eoportal.eumetsat.int/userMgmt/terms.faces\",\"publisher\":{\"@type\":\"Organization\",\"name\":\"EUMETSAT for Copernicus\",\"contactPoint\":{\"@type\":\"ContactPoint\",\"contactType\":\"customer support\",\"telephone\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3660/3770\",\"email\":\"ops@eumetsat.int\",\"url\":\"http://www.eumetsat.int\",\"faxNumber\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3790\"}},\"schemaVersion\":\"3.5\",\"spatialCoverage\":{\"@type\":\"Place\",\"geo\":{\"@type\":\"GeoShape\",\"polygon\":\"-180.0  90.0  180.0  -90.0\"}},\"thumbnailUrl\":\"https://navigator.eumetsat.int/preview/IMG_OLCI_EUMETVIEW_400px.jpg\",\"encodingFormat\":\"GeoTIFF\",\"description\":\"This product is an RGB (Red, Green, Blue) composite based upon data from S3B single swath OLCI L1 NRT products Top-Of-Atmosphere (TOA) radiometric measurements, radiometrically corrected, calibrated and spectrally characterised. The product is composed from data from a combination of the following OLCI bands: 0a02_radiance, Oa06_radiance, Oa08_radiance. The images are generated with a pixel resolution of 0.09 degrees.\\n'Ocean colour' is the change in the colour of the ocean, and other water bodies such as lakes, due to the substances dissolved and particles suspended within the water. The primary objective of OLCI products is to measure the colour of the ocean and land surface and provide information on ocean and land characteristics related to this (e.g. biology). OLCI also provides information on the atmosphere and contributes to climate studies. Sentinel-3 is part of a series of Sentinel satellites, under the umbrella of the EU Copernicus programme.\",\"identifier\":\"EO:EUM:DAT:0182\",\"name\":\"OLCI Level 1B RGB - Sentinel-3B\"}"
#>

#> $hits$hits[[10]]
#> $hits$hits[[10]]$`_index`
#> [1] "csw"

#> $hits$hits[[10]]$`_type`
#> [1] "record"
#> 
#> $hits$hits[[10]]$`_id`
#> [1] "EO:EUM:DAT:0621"
#> 
#> $hits$hits[[10]]$`_score`
#> [1] 1
#> 
#> $hits$hits[[10]]$`_source`
#> $hits$hits[[10]]$`_source`$abstract
#> [1] "Instantaneous precipitation maps over IODC area generated combining geostationary (GEO) IR images from operational geostationary satellites 'calibrated' by precipitation measurements from MW images on Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellites, processed soon after each acquisition of a new image from GEO. The blending algorithm ('Rapid Update’) generates precipitation estimates combining the equivalent blackbody temperatures (TBB) at 10.8 μm with rain rates from all available Passive MW measurements. A separate treatment is performed for convective precipitation: the morphologic information and the enhancement of precipitation estimate is done by the use of NEFODINA software."

The blending algorithm ('Rapid Update’) generates precipitation estimates combining the equivalent blackbody temperatures (TBB) at 10.8 μm with rain rates from all available Passive MW measurements. A separate treatment is performed for convective precipitation: the morphologic information and the enhancement of precipitation estimate is done by the use of NEFODINA software. http://navigator.eumetsat.int/metadata_schema/eum/resources/Codelist/eum_gmxCodelists.xml#MD_ProgressCode Operational EUMETSAT SAF on Support to Operational Hydrology and Water Management H SAF Via Pratica di Mare, 45 c/o Aeroporto M. MSG - Indian Ocean</gco:CharacterString></gmd:title><gmd:alternateTitle><gco:CharacterString>P-IN-SEVIRI_E</gco:CharacterString></gmd:alternateTitle><gmd:alternateTitle><gco:CharacterString>H63</gco:CharacterString></gmd:alternateTitle><gmd:date><gmd:CI_Date><gmd:date><gco:Date>2022-06-09</gco:Date></gmd:date><gmd:dateType><gmd:CI_DateTypeCode codeList=\"http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_DateTypeCode\" codeListValue=\"creation\"/></gmd:dateType></gmd:CI_Date></gmd:date><gmd:identifier><gmd:MD_Identifier><gmd:code><gco:CharacterString>EO:EUM:DAT:0621</gco:CharacterString></gmd:code></gmd:MD_Identifier></gmd:identifier></gmd:CI_Citation></gmd:citation><gmd:abstract><gco:CharacterString>Instantaneous precipitation maps over IODC area generated combining geostationary (GEO) IR images from operational geostationary satellites 'calibrated' by precipitation measurements from MW images on Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellites, processed soon after each acquisition of a new image from GEO. The blending algorithm ('Rapid Update’) generates precipitation estimates combining the equivalent blackbody temperatures (TBB) at 10.8 μm with rain rates from all available Passive MW measurements. A separate treatment is performed for convective precipitation: the morphologic information and the enhancement of precipitation estimate is done by the use of NEFODINA software.</gco:CharacterString></gmd:abstract><gmd:status><gmd:MD_ProgressCode codeList=\"http://navigator.eumetsat.int/metadata_schema/eum/resources/Codelist/eum_gmxCodelists.xml#MD_ProgressCode\" codeListValue=\"Operational\"/></gmd:status><gmd:pointOfContact><gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty><gmd:individualName><gco:CharacterString>EUMETSAT SAF on Support to Operational Hydrology and Water Management</gco:CharacterString></gmd:individualName><gmd:organisationName><gco:CharacterString>H SAF</gco:CharacterString></gmd:organisationName><gmd:contactInfo><gmd:CI_Contact><gmd:phone><gmd:CI_Telephone><gmd:voice><gco:CharacterString/></gmd:voice><gmd:facsimile><gco:CharacterString/></gmd:facsimile></gmd:CI_Telephone></gmd:phone><gmd:address><gmd:CI_Address><gmd:deliveryPoint><gco:CharacterString>Via Pratica di Mare, 45  c/o Aeroporto M. #> $hits$hits[[10]]$`_source`$schemaOrgDefinition
#> [1] "{\"@context\":\"http://schema.org/\",\"@type\":\"Dataset\",\"url\":\"https://navigator.eumetsat.int/product/EO:EUM:DAT:0621\",\"measurementTechnique\":\"Optical\",\"copyrightHolder\":{\"@type\":\"Organization\",\"name\":\"H SAF\",\"contactPoint\":{\"@type\":\"ContactPoint\",\"contactType\":\"customer support\",\"email\":\"us_hsaf@meteoam.it\",\"url\":\"http://h-saf.eumetsat.int\"}},\"copyrightYear\":\"2022\",\"creator\":{\"@type\":\"Organization\",\"name\":\"H SAF\",\"contactPoint\":{\"@type\":\"ContactPoint\",\"contactType\":\"customer support\",\"email\":\"us_hsaf@meteoam.it\",\"url\":\"http://h-saf.eumetsat.int\"}},\"dateCreated\":\"Sun Jan 09 00:06:00 GMT 2022\",\"isAccessibleForFree\":\"false\",\"keywords\":\"GEO,MSG,Weather,GeoTIFF,Precipitation,Meteosat Second Generation (MSG),Optical,SEVIRI\",\"publisher\":{\"@type\":\"Organization\",\"name\":\"H SAF\",\"contactPoint\":{\"@type\":\"ContactPoint\",\"contactType\":\"customer support\",\"email\":\"us_hsaf@meteoam.it\",\"url\":\"http://h-saf.eumetsat.int\"}},\"schemaVersion\":\"3.5\",\"spatialCoverage\":{\"@type\":\"Place\",\"geo\":{\"@type\":\"GeoShape\",\"polygon\":\"-34.5  67.5  125.5  -60.0\"}},\"temporalCoverage\":\"Sun Jan 09 00:06:00 GMT 2022 / Mon Jan 30 17:24:30 GMT 2023\",\"thumbnailUrl\":\"https://navigator.eumetsat.int/preview/h63_20220701_1115_fdk.png\",\"encodingFormat\":\"GeoTIFF\",\"description\":\"Instantaneous precipitation maps over IODC area generated combining geostationary (GEO) IR images from operational geostationary satellites 'calibrated' by precipitation measurements from MW images on Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellites, processed soon after each acquisition of a new image from GEO. The blending algorithm ('Rapid Update’) generates precipitation estimates combining the equivalent blackbody temperatures (TBB) at 10.8 μm with rain rates from all available Passive MW measurements. A separate treatment is performed for convective precipitation: the morphologic information and the enhancement of precipitation estimate is done by the use of NEFODINA software.\",\"identifier\":\"EO:EUM:DAT:0621\",\"name\":\"Precipitation rate at ground by GEO/IR supported by LEO/MW - MSG - Indian Ocean\"}"
#>

#> [[1]]$`_score`
#> [1] 1
#> 
#> [[1]]$`_source`
#> [[1]]$`_source`$abstract
#> [1] "The E-View product is an RGB (Red, Green, Blue) composite based upon data from the SEVIRI instrument. It is dedicated to detailed cloud monitoring of the European region. It is based on data from the SEVIRI High Resolution Visible channel combined with data from the IR10.8 channel that provides the temperature information (blue component)."

(MSG)</gco:CharacterString></gmi:description><gmi:instrument><eum:MI_EUMInstrument><gmi:citation><gmd:CI_Citation><gmd:title><gco:CharacterString>SEVIRI</gco:CharacterString></gmd:title><gmd:date><gmd:CI_Date><gmd:date><gco:Date>2008-06-01</gco:Date></gmd:date><gmd:dateType><gmd:CI_DateTypeCode codeListValue=\"creation\"/></gmd:dateType></gmd:CI_Date></gmd:date><gmd:identifier><gmd:MD_Identifier><gmd:code><gco:CharacterString>SEVIRI</gco:CharacterString></gmd:code></gmd:MD_Identifier></gmd:identifier></gmd:CI_Citation></gmi:citation><gmi:type><gmi:MI_SensorTypeCode #> [[1]]$`_source`$schemaOrgDefinition
#> [1] "{\"@context\":\"http://schema.org/\",\"@type\":\"Dataset\",\"url\":\"https://navigator.eumetsat.int/product/EO:EUM:DAT:MSG:EVIEW\",\"measurementTechnique\":\"Optical\",\"copyrightHolder\":{\"@type\":\"Organization\",\"name\":\"EUMETSAT\",\"contactPoint\":{\"@type\":\"ContactPoint\",\"contactType\":\"customer support\",\"telephone\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3660/3770\",\"email\":\"ops@eumetsat.int\",\"url\":\"http://www.eumetsat.int\",\"faxNumber\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3790\"}},\"creator\":{\"@type\":\"Organization\",\"name\":\"EUMETSAT\",\"contactPoint\":{\"@type\":\"ContactPoint\",\"contactType\":\"customer support\",\"telephone\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3660/3770\",\"email\":\"ops@eumetsat.int\",\"url\":\"http://www.eumetsat.int\",\"faxNumber\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3790\"}},\"dateModified\":\"Fri Jan 23 00:11:00 GMT 2009\",\"isAccessibleForFree\":\"false\",\"keywords\":\"GEO,MSG,GeoTIFF,Meteosat Second Generation (MSG),Atmosphere,Optical,Cloud,SEVIRI\",\"license\":\"https://eoportal.eumetsat.int/userMgmt/terms.faces\",\"publisher\":{\"@type\":\"Organization\",\"name\":\"EUMETSAT\",\"contactPoint\":{\"@type\":\"ContactPoint\",\"contactType\":\"customer support\",\"telephone\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3660/3770\",\"email\":\"ops@eumetsat.int\",\"url\":\"http://www.eumetsat.int\",\"faxNumber\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3790\"}},\"schemaVersion\":\"3.5\",\"spatialCoverage\":{\"@type\":\"Place\",\"geo\":{\"@type\":\"GeoShape\",\"polygon\":\"-79.0  81.0  79.0  -81.0\"}},\"thumbnailUrl\":\"https://navigator.eumetsat.int/preview/FRAME_OIS_RGB-12-12-9i-segment15_0911231300.jpg\",\"encodingFormat\":\"GeoTIFF\",\"description\":\"The E-View product is an RGB (Red, Green, Blue) composite based upon data from the SEVIRI instrument. It is dedicated to detailed cloud monitoring of the European region. It is based on data from the SEVIRI High Resolution Visible channel combined with data from the IR10.8 channel that provides the temperature information (blue component).\",\"identifier\":\"EO:EUM:DAT:MSG:EVIEW\",\"name\":\"European HRV RGB\"}"
#>

#> [[2]]$`_index`
#> [1] "csw"

#> [[2]]$`_type`
#> [1] "record"

#> [[2]]$`_id`
#> [1] "EO:EUM:DAT:MSG:SNOW-IODC"
#> 
#> [[2]]$`_score`
#> [1] 1
#> 
#> [[2]]$`_source`
#> [[2]]$`_source`$abstract
#> [1] "The main application of the Snow RGB (Red, Green, Blue) is the detection of fog / low clouds and snow during day-time. In this color scheme snow appears red because of the strong absorption in the NIR1.6 and IR3.9 channels (no green and blue), while fog / low clouds appear whitish. Small particle ice cloud appears orange, while large particle ice cloud appears with greater red component. Snow on the ground appears as full red, because its grains are usually much larger than cloud ice particles. \r\n\r\nFrom 1 June 2022, Meteosat-9 at 45.5° E is the prime satellite for the IODC service, replacing Meteosat-8 (located at 41.5° E while in operation)."

Snow RGB Quick Guide</gco:CharacterString></gmd:name><gmd:function><gmd:CI_OnLineFunctionCode codeList=\"http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_RoleCode\" codeListValue=\"author\"/></gmd:role></gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty></gmd:citedResponsibleParty></gmd:CI_Citation></gmd:citation><gmd:abstract><gco:CharacterString>The main application of the Snow RGB (Red, Green, Blue) is the detection of fog / low clouds and snow during day-time. In this color scheme snow appears red because of the strong absorption in the NIR1.6 and IR3.9 channels (no green and blue), while fog / low clouds appear whitish. Small particle ice cloud appears orange, while large particle ice cloud appears with greater red component. Snow on the ground appears as full red, because its grains are usually much larger than cloud ice particles. &#xD;\n&#xD;\nFrom 1 June 2022, Meteosat-9 at 45.5° E is the prime satellite for the IODC service, replacing Meteosat-8 (located at 41.5° E while in operation).</gco:CharacterString></gmd:abstract><gmd:status><gmd:MD_ProgressCode codeList=\"http://navigator.eumetsat.int/metadata_schema/eum/resources/Codelist/eum_gmxCodelists.xml#MD_ProgressCode\" #> [[2]]$`_source`$schemaOrgDefinition
#> [1] "{\"@context\":\"http://schema.org/\",\"@type\":\"Dataset\",\"url\":\"https://navigator.eumetsat.int/product/EO:EUM:DAT:MSG:SNOW-IODC\",\"measurementTechnique\":\"Optical\",\"copyrightHolder\":{\"@type\":\"Organization\",\"name\":\"EUMETSAT\",\"contactPoint\":{\"@type\":\"ContactPoint\",\"contactType\":\"customer support\",\"telephone\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3660/3770\",\"email\":\"ops@eumetsat.int\",\"url\":\"http://www.eumetsat.int\",\"faxNumber\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3790\"}},\"copyrightYear\":\"2020\",\"creator\":{\"@type\":\"Organization\",\"name\":\"EUMETSAT\",\"contactPoint\":{\"@type\":\"ContactPoint\",\"contactType\":\"customer support\",\"telephone\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3660/3770\",\"email\":\"ops@eumetsat.int\",\"url\":\"http://www.eumetsat.int\",\"faxNumber\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3790\"}},\"dateCreated\":\"Wed Jan 01 00:09:00 GMT 2020\",\"isAccessibleForFree\":\"false\",\"keywords\":\"GEO,MSG,Weather,GeoTIFF,Meteosat Second Generation (MSG),Optical,Snow and Ice,Atmospheric Composition,SEVIRI,Land\",\"license\":\"https://eoportal.eumetsat.int/userMgmt/terms.faces\",\"publisher\":{\"@type\":\"Organization\",\"name\":\"EUMETSAT\",\"contactPoint\":{\"@type\":\"ContactPoint\",\"contactType\":\"customer support\",\"telephone\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3660/3770\",\"email\":\"ops@eumetsat.int\",\"url\":\"http://www.eumetsat.int\",\"faxNumber\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3790\"}},\"schemaVersion\":\"3.5\",\"spatialCoverage\":{\"@type\":\"Place\",\"geo\":{\"@type\":\"GeoShape\",\"polygon\":\"-29.5  75.0  120.5  -75.0\"}},\"temporalCoverage\":\"Wed Jan 01 00:09:00 GMT 2020 / Thu Dec 08 14:08:02 GMT 2022\",\"thumbnailUrl\":\"https://navigator.eumetsat.int/preview/Snow_RGB_IODC.jpg\",\"encodingFormat\":\"GeoTIFF\",\"description\":\"The main application of the Snow RGB (Red, Green, Blue) is the detection of fog / low clouds and snow during day-time. In this color scheme snow appears red because of the strong absorption in the NIR1.6 and IR3.9 channels (no green and blue), while fog / low clouds appear whitish. Small particle ice cloud appears orange, while large particle ice cloud appears with greater red component. Snow on the ground appears as full red, because its grains are usually much larger than cloud ice particles. \\r\\n\\r\\nFrom 1 June 2022, Meteosat-9 at 45.5° E is the prime satellite for the IODC service, replacing Meteosat-8 (located at 41.5° E while in operation).\",\"identifier\":\"EO:EUM:DAT:MSG:SNOW-IODC\",\"name\":\"Snow RGB - MSG - Indian Ocean\"}"
#> 
#>

#> [[3]]$`_id`

#> [[3]]$`_score`
#> [1] 1
#> 
#> [[3]]$`_source`
#> [[3]]$`_source`$abstract
#> [1] "Sea Surface Temperature (SST) is the kinetic temperature of a water body at a defined depth. Although SLSTR measures an infrared radiometric temperature, it is provided as a kinetic temperature by considering the emissivity of the water body as part of the SST retrieval process. It is important to note that the SLSTR instruments return SST measurements for the ocean 'skin'. Due to the limited penetration of thermal infra-red radiation through the water column, this corresponds to the temperature in the top few tens of micrometres. \nAt night, the skin temperature is typically a few tenths of a degree cooler than the temperature measured by in situ systems; in the day, the skin can be considerably higher if strong diurnal warming is present. For more details please see “What is SST?” on the GHRSST web pages.\nThe SST measurement is obtained by means of a highly accurate calibration of the three infra-red channels at 3.74, 10.85 and 12 µm (S7-S8-S9). Corrections for water vapour atmospheric absorption are performed using a triple window at night, and a split window during the day as the 3.7 µm channel is not used due to solar contamination. \nEach on-ground pixel is viewed twice, via nadir and oblique views with different atmospheric path lengths, allowing for correction for aerosol effects. Consequently, there are four possible retrieved SSTs, referred to as N2 (nadir-only 11 µm and 12 µm), N3 (nadir-only 3.7 µm, 11 µm and 12 µm), D2 (dual-view 11 µm and 12 µm) and D3 (dual-view 3.7 µm, 11 µm and 12 µm). A fifth retrieval algorithm, N3R is similar to N3, but uses the property of “aerosol robustness”, which is applicable in areas of high atmospheric aerosol content, e.g. near volcanoes.\nThe product is derived from SLSTR L2 NRT data. Following derivation was applied to select the SST pixels to be plotted from WST file: \n- if the observation is in the nadir-only / single-view part of swath (i.e. \"sst_algorithm_types\" is N2, N3, N3R) then SST = sea_surface_temperature\n- If the observation is in the dual-view part of swath ((i.e. \"sst_algorithm_types\" is D2 or D3) then SST = sea_surface_temperature - dual_nadir_sst_difference.\nBesides, the following flags were used to select which pixels to represent and display: (quality_level >=3)  and  (l2p_flags.land == 0) and  (l2p_flags.lake == 0) \nThe image is an incrementally accumulated product of all the orbits over an entire day from both Sentinel-3A and -3B.\nThe SLSTR instrument and ground processing system are required to produce SST retrievals routinely from the corresponding brightness temperatures with an absolute accuracy of better than 0.3 K, globally, both for a single sample and when averaged over areas of 0.5° longitude by 0.5° latitude, under certain cloud-free conditions (i.e. >20% cloud-free samples within each area). The SLSTR instrument also has a temporal stability of 0.1 K/decade."

#> [1] "EO:EUM:DAT:0028 http://www.w3.org/WAI/ER/IG/ert/iso639.htm eng http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#MD_ScopeCode series theme.par.Ocean theme.par.Sea_Surface_Temperature dis.View sat.Sentinel-3 view.Satellite.Sentinel 3AB.Products view.Theme.Ocean European Organisation for the Exploitation of Meteorological Satellites EUMETSAT +49(0)6151-807 3660/3770 +49(0)6151-807 3790 EUMETSAT Allee 1 Darmstadt Hessen 64295 Germany ops@eumetsat.int http://www.eumetsat.int http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/ML_gmxCodelists.xml#MD_ScopeCode pointOfContact pointOfContact 2020-03-04 ISO19115 2003/Cor.1:2006 SLSTR Level 2 SST Daily Accumulated - Sentinel-3 SL_2_SST_ACC 2019-04-30 http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_DateTypeCode creation EO:EUM:DAT:0028 https://www.eumetsat.int/website/home/Satellites/CurrentSatellites/Sentinel3/SeaSurfaceTemperatureServices/index.html EUMETSAT Sea Surface Temperature page http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_OnLineFunctionCode information http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_RoleCode author https://www.eumetsat.int/media/45983 Sentinel-3 SLSTR Marine User Handbook http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_OnLineFunctionCode information http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_RoleCode author https://www.eumetsat.int/media/47365 Product Data Format Specification - SLSTR Level 1 & Level 2 Instrument Products http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_OnLineFunctionCode information http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_RoleCode author https://www.eumetsat.int/media/38642 Product Data Format Specification - Product Structures http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_OnLineFunctionCode information http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_RoleCode author http://www.eumetsat.int/website/home/Satellites/CurrentSatellites/Sentinel3/SeaSurfaceTemperatureServices/index.html#PN SLSTR Product Notices http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_OnLineFunctionCode information http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_RoleCode author https://www.eumetsat.int/slstr-processing-baselines SLSTR Processing Baselines http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_OnLineFunctionCode information http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_RoleCode author http://www.eumetsat.int/website/home/Satellites/CurrentSatellites/Sentinel3/SeaSurfaceTemperatureServices/index.html#SLSTRDocs SLSTR Documents (ATBD etc) http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_OnLineFunctionCode information http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_RoleCode author Sea Surface Temperature (SST) is the kinetic temperature of a water body at a defined depth. Although SLSTR measures an infrared radiometric temperature, it is provided as a kinetic temperature by considering the emissivity of the water body as part of the SST retrieval process. It is important to note that the SLSTR instruments return SST measurements for the ocean 'skin'. Due to the limited penetration of thermal infra-red radiation through the water column, this corresponds to the temperature in the top few tens of micrometres. At night, the skin temperature is typically a few tenths of a degree cooler than the temperature measured by in situ systems; in the day, the skin can be considerably higher if strong diurnal warming is present. For more details please see “What is SST?” on the GHRSST web pages. The SST measurement is obtained by means of a highly accurate calibration of the three infra-red channels at 3.74, 10.85 and 12 µm (S7-S8-S9). Corrections for water vapour atmospheric absorption are performed using a triple window at night, and a split window during the day as the 3.7 µm channel is not used due to solar contamination. Each on-ground pixel is viewed twice, via nadir and oblique views with different atmospheric path lengths, allowing for correction for aerosol effects. Consequently, there are four possible retrieved SSTs, referred to as N2 (nadir-only 11 µm and 12 µm), N3 (nadir-only 3.7 µm, 11 µm and 12 µm), D2 (dual-view 11 µm and 12 µm) and D3 (dual-view 3.7 µm, 11 µm and 12 µm). A fifth retrieval algorithm, N3R is similar to N3, but uses the property of “aerosol robustness”, which is applicable in areas of high atmospheric aerosol content, e.g. near volcanoes. The product is derived from SLSTR L2 NRT data. Following derivation was applied to select the SST pixels to be plotted from WST file: - if the observation is in the nadir-only / single-view part of swath (i.e. \"sst_algorithm_types\" is N2, N3, N3R) then SST = sea_surface_temperature - If the observation is in the dual-view part of swath ((i.e. \"sst_algorithm_types\" is D2 or D3) then SST = sea_surface_temperature - dual_nadir_sst_difference. Besides, the following flags were used to select which pixels to represent and display: (quality_level >=3) and (l2p_flags.land == 0) and (l2p_flags.lake == 0) The image is an incrementally accumulated product of all the orbits over an entire day from both Sentinel-3A and -3B. The SLSTR instrument and ground processing system are required to produce SST retrievals routinely from the corresponding brightness temperatures with an absolute accuracy of better than 0.3 K, globally, both for a single sample and when averaged over areas of 0.5° longitude by 0.5° latitude, under certain cloud-free conditions (i.e. >20% cloud-free samples within each area). The SLSTR instrument also has a temporal stability of 0.1 K/decade. http://navigator.eumetsat.int/metadata_schema/eum/resources/Codelist/eum_gmxCodelists.xml#MD_ProgressCode Operational European Organisation for the Exploitation of Meteorological Satellites EUMETSAT for Copernicus +49(0)6151-807 3660/3770 +49(0)6151-807 3790 EUMETSAT Allee 1 Darmstadt Hessen 64295 Germany ops@eumetsat.int http://www.eumetsat.int http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/ML_gmxCodelists.xml#MD_ScopeCode originator originator https://navigator.eumetsat.int/preview/SL_L2_SST_ACC.png Ocean Sea Surface Temperature http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#MD_KeywordTypeCode theme - http://standards.iso.org/iso/19139/resources/gmxCodelists.xml#MD_RestrictionCode otherRestrictions http://standards.iso.org/iso/19139/resources/gmxCodelists.xml#MD_RestrictionCode otherRestrictions https://www.eumetsat.int/eumetsat-data-licensing NoConditions http://www.w3.org/WAI/ER/IG/ert/iso639.htm eng http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_CharacterSetCode utf8 climatologyMeteorologyAtmosphere x811aaa unknown unknown true -180 180 -90 90 Global - http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#MD_CoverageContentTypeCode image European Organisation for the Exploitation of Meteorological Satellites EUMETSAT +49(0)6151-807 3660/3770 +49(0)6151-807 3790 EUMETSAT Allee 1 Darmstadt Hessen 64295 Germany ops@eumetsat.int http://www.eumetsat.int http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/ML_gmxCodelists.xml#MD_ScopeCode distributor distributor https://eumetview.eumetsat.int/mapviewer/?product=EO:EUM:DAT:0028 https View on EUMETView CI_OnLineFunctionCode order https://eumetview.eumetsat.int/geoserv/wms?SERVICE=WMS&REQUEST=GetMap&TRANSPARENT=TRUE&EXCEPTIONS=INIMAGE&VERSION=1.3.0&LAYERS=copernicus%3Asentinel3ab_accumulated_slstr_l2_sst_fulres_platecarre&STYLES=sst_medspiration&SRS=EPSG%3A4326&WIDTH=3840&HEIGHT=1569&BBOX=-85.44,-180,90,180.01&FORMAT=image/geotiff https Latest image CI_OnLineFunctionCode order Web Imagery GeoTIFF - copernicus-sentinel3ab_accumulated_slstr_l2_sst_fulres_platecarre.tif MB 23 ~14 (per day) false http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#MD_ScopeCode series - Sentinel-3 Sentinel-3 SLSTR 2008-06-01 http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_DateTypeCode creation SLSTR z215aaa z215aaa http://navigator.eumetsat.int/metadata_schema/eum/resources/Codelist/eum_gmxCodelists.xml#CI_SensorTypeCode Optical http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_OrbitTypeCode LEO"

Product Notices</gco:CharacterString></gmd:name><gmd:function><gmd:CI_OnLineFunctionCode codeListValue=\"author\"/></gmd:role></gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty></gmd:citedResponsibleParty><gmd:citedResponsibleParty><gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty><gmd:contactInfo><gmd:CI_Contact><gmd:onlineResource><gmd:CI_OnlineResource><gmd:linkage><gmd:URL>https://www.eumetsat.int/slstr-processing-baselines</gmd:URL></gmd:linkage><gmd:name><gco:CharacterString>SLSTR Processing Baselines</gco:CharacterString></gmd:name><gmd:function><gmd:CI_OnLineFunctionCode codeList=\"http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_OnLineFunctionCode\" codeListValue=\"information\"/></gmd:function></gmd:CI_OnlineResource></gmd:onlineResource></gmd:CI_Contact></gmd:contactInfo><gmd:role><gmd:CI_RoleCode codeList=\"http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_RoleCode\" codeListValue=\"author\"/></gmd:role></gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty></gmd:citedResponsibleParty><gmd:citedResponsibleParty><gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty><gmd:contactInfo><gmd:CI_Contact><gmd:onlineResource><gmd:CI_OnlineResource><gmd:linkage><gmd:URL>http://www.eumetsat.int/website/home/Satellites/CurrentSatellites/Sentinel3/SeaSurfaceTemperatureServices/index.html#SLSTRDocs</gmd:URL></gmd:linkage><gmd:name><gco:CharacterString>SLSTR Documents (ATBD etc)</gco:CharacterString></gmd:name><gmd:function><gmd:CI_OnLineFunctionCode codeList=\"http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_OnLineFunctionCode\" codeListValue=\"information\"/></gmd:function></gmd:CI_OnlineResource></gmd:onlineResource></gmd:CI_Contact></gmd:contactInfo><gmd:role><gmd:CI_RoleCode codeList=\"http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_RoleCode\" codeListValue=\"author\"/></gmd:role></gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty></gmd:citedResponsibleParty></gmd:CI_Citation></gmd:citation><gmd:abstract><gco:CharacterString>Sea Surface Temperature (SST) is the kinetic temperature of a water body at a defined depth. Although SLSTR measures an infrared radiometric temperature, it is provided as a kinetic temperature by considering the emissivity of the water body as part of the SST retrieval process. It is important to note that the SLSTR instruments return SST measurements for the ocean 'skin'. Due to the limited penetration of thermal infra-red radiation through the water column, this corresponds to the temperature in the top few tens of micrometres. \nAt night, the skin temperature is typically a few tenths of a degree cooler than the temperature measured by in situ systems; in the day, the skin can be considerably higher if strong diurnal warming is present. For more details please see “What is SST?” on the GHRSST web pages.\nThe SST measurement is obtained by means of a highly accurate calibration of the three infra-red channels at 3.74, 10.85 and 12 µm (S7-S8-S9). Corrections for water vapour atmospheric absorption are performed using a triple window at night, and a split window during the day as the 3.7 µm channel is not used due to solar contamination. \nEach on-ground pixel is viewed twice, via nadir and oblique views with different atmospheric path lengths, allowing for correction for aerosol effects. Consequently, there are four possible retrieved SSTs, referred to as N2 (nadir-only 11 µm and 12 µm), N3 (nadir-only 3.7 µm, 11 µm and 12 µm), D2 (dual-view 11 µm and 12 µm) and D3 (dual-view 3.7 µm, 11 µm and 12 µm). A fifth retrieval algorithm, N3R is similar to N3, but uses the property of “aerosol robustness”, which is applicable in areas of high atmospheric aerosol content, e.g. near volcanoes.\nThe product is derived from SLSTR L2 NRT data. Following derivation was applied to select the SST pixels to be plotted from WST file: \n- if the observation is in the nadir-only / single-view part of swath (i.e. \"sst_algorithm_types\" is N2, N3, N3R) then SST = sea_surface_temperature\n- If the observation is in the dual-view part of swath ((i.e. \"sst_algorithm_types\" is D2 or D3) then SST = sea_surface_temperature - dual_nadir_sst_difference.\nBesides, the following flags were used to select which pixels to represent and display: (quality_level &gt;=3)  and  (l2p_flags.land == 0) and  (l2p_flags.lake == 0) \nThe image is an incrementally accumulated product of all the orbits over an entire day from both Sentinel-3A and -3B.\nThe SLSTR instrument and ground processing system are required to produce SST retrievals routinely from the corresponding brightness temperatures with an absolute accuracy of better than 0.3 K, globally, both for a single sample and when averaged over areas of 0.5° longitude by 0.5° latitude, under certain cloud-free conditions (i.e. &gt;20% cloud-free samples within each area). The SLSTR instrument also has a temporal stability of 0.1 K/decade.</gco:CharacterString></gmd:abstract><gmd:status><gmd:MD_ProgressCode codeList=\"http://navigator.eumetsat.int/metadata_schema/eum/resources/Codelist/eum_gmxCodelists.xml#MD_ProgressCode\" codeListValue=\"Operational\"/></gmd:status><gmd:pointOfContact><gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty><gmd:individualName><gco:CharacterString>European Organisation for the Exploitation of Meteorological Satellites</gco:CharacterString></gmd:individualName><gmd:organisationName><gco:CharacterString>EUMETSAT for codeListValue=\"originator\">originator</gmd:CI_RoleCode></gmd:role></gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty></gmd:pointOfContact><gmd:graphicOverview><gmd:MD_BrowseGraphic><gmd:fileName><gco:CharacterString>https://navigator.eumetsat.int/preview/SL_L2_SST_ACC.png</gco:CharacterString></gmd:fileName></gmd:MD_BrowseGraphic></gmd:graphicOverview><gmd:descriptiveKeywords><gmd:MD_Keywords><gmd:keyword><gco:CharacterString>Ocean</gco:CharacterString></gmd:keyword><gmd:keyword><gco:CharacterString>Sea Surface Temperature</gco:CharacterString></gmd:keyword><gmd:type><gmd:MD_KeywordTypeCode codeList=\"http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#MD_KeywordTypeCode\" codeListValue=\"utf8\"/></gmd:characterSet><gmd:topicCategory><gmd:MD_TopicCategoryCode>climatologyMeteorologyAtmosphere</gmd:MD_TopicCategoryCode></gmd:topicCategory><gmd:extent><gmd:EX_Extent><gmd:temporalElement><gmd:EX_TemporalExtent><gmd:extent><gml:TimePeriod #> [[3]]$`_source`$schemaOrgDefinition
#> [1] "{\"@context\":\"http://schema.org/\",\"@type\":\"Dataset\",\"url\":\"https://navigator.eumetsat.int/product/EO:EUM:DAT:0028\",\"measurementTechnique\":\"Optical\",\"copyrightHolder\":{\"@type\":\"Organization\",\"name\":\"EUMETSAT for Copernicus\",\"contactPoint\":{\"@type\":\"ContactPoint\",\"contactType\":\"customer support\",\"telephone\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3660/3770\",\"email\":\"ops@eumetsat.int\",\"url\":\"http://www.eumetsat.int\",\"faxNumber\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3790\"}},\"creator\":{\"@type\":\"Organization\",\"name\":\"EUMETSAT for Copernicus\",\"contactPoint\":{\"@type\":\"ContactPoint\",\"contactType\":\"customer support\",\"telephone\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3660/3770\",\"email\":\"ops@eumetsat.int\",\"url\":\"http://www.eumetsat.int\",\"faxNumber\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3790\"}},\"isAccessibleForFree\":\"false\",\"keywords\":\"GeoTIFF,Sentinel-3,Optical,LEO,Ocean,Sea Surface Temperature,SLSTR\",\"license\":\"https://eoportal.eumetsat.int/userMgmt/terms.faces\",\"publisher\":{\"@type\":\"Organization\",\"name\":\"EUMETSAT for Copernicus\",\"contactPoint\":{\"@type\":\"ContactPoint\",\"contactType\":\"customer support\",\"telephone\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3660/3770\",\"email\":\"ops@eumetsat.int\",\"url\":\"http://www.eumetsat.int\",\"faxNumber\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3790\"}},\"schemaVersion\":\"3.5\",\"spatialCoverage\":{\"@type\":\"Place\",\"geo\":{\"@type\":\"GeoShape\",\"polygon\":\"-180.0  90.0  180.0  -90.0\"}},\"thumbnailUrl\":\"https://navigator.eumetsat.int/preview/SL_L2_SST_ACC.png\",\"encodingFormat\":\"GeoTIFF\",\"description\":\"Sea Surface Temperature (SST) is the kinetic temperature of a water body at a defined depth. Although SLSTR measures an infrared radiometric temperature, it is provided as a kinetic temperature by considering the emissivity of the water body as part of the SST retrieval process. It is important to note that the SLSTR instruments return SST measurements for the ocean 'skin'. Due to the limited penetration of thermal infra-red radiation through the water column, this corresponds to the temperature in the top few tens of micrometres. \\nAt night, the skin temperature is typically a few tenths of a degree cooler than the temperature measured by in situ systems; in the day, the skin can be considerably higher if strong diurnal warming is present. For more details please see “What is SST?” on the GHRSST web pages.\\nThe SST measurement is obtained by means of a highly accurate calibration of the three infra-red channels at 3.74, 10.85 and 12 µm (S7-S8-S9). Corrections for water vapour atmospheric absorption are performed using a triple window at night, and a split window during the day as the 3.7 µm channel is not used due to solar contamination. \\nEach on-ground pixel is viewed twice, via nadir and oblique views with different atmospheric path lengths, allowing for correction for aerosol effects. Consequently, there are four possible retrieved SSTs, referred to as N2 (nadir-only 11 µm and 12 µm), N3 (nadir-only 3.7 µm, 11 µm and 12 µm), D2 (dual-view 11 µm and 12 µm) and D3 (dual-view 3.7 µm, 11 µm and 12 µm). A fifth retrieval algorithm, N3R is similar to N3, but uses the property of “aerosol robustness”, which is applicable in areas of high atmospheric aerosol content, e.g. near volcanoes.\\nThe product is derived from SLSTR L2 NRT data. Following derivation was applied to select the SST pixels to be plotted from WST file: \\n- if the observation is in the nadir-only / single-view part of swath (i.e. \\\"sst_algorithm_types\\\" is N2, N3, N3R) then SST = sea_surface_temperature\\n- If the observation is in the dual-view part of swath ((i.e. \\\"sst_algorithm_types\\\" is D2 or D3) then SST = sea_surface_temperature - dual_nadir_sst_difference.\\nBesides, the following flags were used to select which pixels to represent and display: (quality_level >=3)  and  (l2p_flags.land == 0) and  (l2p_flags.lake == 0) \\nThe image is an incrementally accumulated product of all the orbits over an entire day from both Sentinel-3A and -3B.\\nThe SLSTR instrument and ground processing system are required to produce SST retrievals routinely from the corresponding brightness temperatures with an absolute accuracy of better than 0.3 K, globally, both for a single sample and when averaged over areas of 0.5° longitude by 0.5° latitude, under certain cloud-free conditions (i.e. >20% cloud-free samples within each area). The SLSTR instrument also has a temporal stability of 0.1 K/decade.\",\"identifier\":\"EO:EUM:DAT:0028\",\"name\":\"SLSTR Level 2 SST Daily Accumulated - Sentinel-3\"}"
#> 
#> 
#> 
#> [[4]]
#> [[4]]$`_index`
#> [1] "csw"
#> 
#> [[4]]$`_type`
#> [1] "record"
#> 
#> [[4]]$`_id`
#> [1] "EO:EUM:DAT:0199"
#> 
#> [[4]]$`_score`
#> [1] 1
#> 
#> [[4]]$`_source`
#> [[4]]$`_source`$abstract
#> [1] "This is an image of Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer (AVHRR) channel IR 10.8 Level 1b Brightness Temperatures, accumulated over the last 6 orbits. The indicated time represents the end of the last orbit (when the satellite crosses the equator in the ascending node). \nThe IR10.8 channel is an atmospheric window channel (where the absorption of the gas molecules is low), and it helps in distinguishing thick clouds by to their cloud top temperatures.  \nThe accumulated images are displayed mapping the same temperature range for day and night, i.e. 220 K-310 K, in order to have quite homogeneous images during the entire 24 hours and also to have a good contrast in the polar regions.\nThe Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer (AVHRR) is a multipurpose imaging instrument used for global monitoring of cloud cover, sea surface temperature, ice, snow and vegetation cover characteristics. It operates at 6 different channels simultaneously at a spatial resolution of about 1 Km near-nadir.\nAVHRR has many applications in oceanography, meteorology and terrestrial sciences:\n- Multi-Channel SST (MCSST) is the main geophysical parameter of use in AVHRR oceanographic applications. \n- Another oceanographic application of AVHRR data is in the study of sea ice. Properly filtered for clouds over ice, AVHRR imagery can be used to compute sea ice concentration, type and ice edge location. It can also be used to compute ice motion.\n- Multi-channel imagery from the AVHRR has also proven to be useful in snow cover mapping. The frequent coverage of the AVHRR is the prime advantage in being able to distinguish clouds from snow cover with their similar albedo signature. Combined with topographic relief information, snow cover from AVHRR can be converted to snow-water equivalent to give an estimate of the amount of water reserve represented by the winter snow pack.\n- Day and night cloud mapping is the main application of AVHRR data in meteorology, especially at high latitudes where data from geostationary satellites are severely affected by Earth curvature. AVHRR's frequent day/night synoptic coverage and high horizontal resolution are features that make the system unique for the study of land surface. "

#> [[4]]$`_source`$fulltext
#> [1] "EO:EUM:DAT:0199 http://www.w3.org/WAI/ER/IG/ert/iso639.htm eng http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#MD_ScopeCode series theme.par.Atmosphere theme.par.Land theme.par.Level_1_Data theme.par.Ocean dis.View sat.Metop sat.Metop.AVHRR view.Satellite.Metop C.Channels view.Theme.Atmospheric Composition European Organisation for the Exploitation of Meteorological Satellites EUMETSAT +49(0)6151-807 3660/3770 +49(0)6151-807 3790 EUMETSAT Allee 1 Darmstadt Hessen 64295 Germany ops@eumetsat.int http://www.eumetsat.int http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/ML_gmxCodelists.xml#MD_ScopeCode pointOfContact pointOfContact 2020-03-11 ISO19115 2003/Cor.1:2006 AVHRR IR10.8 6 orbits accumulated - Metop C 2019-11-04 http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_DateTypeCode creation EO:EUM:DAT:0199 https://www.eumetsat.int/media/39253 AVHRR - Factsheet http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_OnLineFunctionCode information http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_RoleCode author https://www.eumetsat.int/media/15351 AVHRR Level 1B Product Guide http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_OnLineFunctionCode information http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_RoleCode author https://www.eumetsat.int/media/38675 AVHRR 3 Level 1 Product Format Specification http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_OnLineFunctionCode information http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_RoleCode author https://www.eumetsat.int/media/38128 AVHRR L1 Product Generation Specification http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_OnLineFunctionCode information http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_RoleCode author This is an image of Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer (AVHRR) channel IR 10.8 Level 1b Brightness Temperatures, accumulated over the last 6 orbits. The indicated time represents the end of the last orbit (when the satellite crosses the equator in the ascending node). The IR10.8 channel is an atmospheric window channel (where the absorption of the gas molecules is low), and it helps in distinguishing thick clouds by to their cloud top temperatures.  The accumulated images are displayed mapping the same temperature range for day and night, i.e. 220 K-310 K, in order to have quite homogeneous images during the entire 24 hours and also to have a good contrast in the polar regions. The Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer (AVHRR) is a multipurpose imaging instrument used for global monitoring of cloud cover, sea surface temperature, ice, snow and vegetation cover characteristics. It operates at 6 different channels simultaneously at a spatial resolution of about 1 Km near-nadir. AVHRR has many applications in oceanography, meteorology and terrestrial sciences: - Multi-Channel SST (MCSST) is the main geophysical parameter of use in AVHRR oceanographic applications. - Another oceanographic application of AVHRR data is in the study of sea ice. Properly filtered for clouds over ice, AVHRR imagery can be used to compute sea ice concentration, type and ice edge location. It can also be used to compute ice motion. - Multi-channel imagery from the AVHRR has also proven to be useful in snow cover mapping. The frequent coverage of the AVHRR is the prime advantage in being able to distinguish clouds from snow cover with their similar albedo signature. Combined with topographic relief information, snow cover from AVHRR can be converted to snow-water equivalent to give an estimate of the amount of water reserve represented by the winter snow pack. - Day and night cloud mapping is the main application of AVHRR data in meteorology, especially at high latitudes where data from geostationary satellites are severely affected by Earth curvature. AVHRR's frequent day/night synoptic coverage and high horizontal resolution are features that make the system unique for the study of land surface.  http://navigator.eumetsat.int/metadata_schema/eum/resources/Codelist/eum_gmxCodelists.xml#MD_ProgressCode Operational European Organisation for the Exploitation of Meteorological Satellites EUMETSAT +49(0)6151-807 3660/3770 +49(0)6151-807 3790 EUMETSAT Allee 1 Darmstadt Hessen 64295 Germany ops@eumetsat.int http://www.eumetsat.int http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/ML_gmxCodelists.xml#MD_ScopeCode originator originator https://navigator.eumetsat.int/preview/eps-metop1_ir108_THUMBNAIL_small.jpg Atmosphere Land Level 1 Data Ocean http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#MD_KeywordTypeCode theme - http://standards.iso.org/iso/19139/resources/gmxCodelists.xml#MD_RestrictionCode otherRestrictions http://standards.iso.org/iso/19139/resources/gmxCodelists.xml#MD_RestrictionCode otherRestrictions https://www.eumetsat.int/eumetsat-data-licensing NoConditions http://www.w3.org/WAI/ER/IG/ert/iso639.htm eng http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_CharacterSetCode utf8 climatologyMeteorologyAtmosphere x832aaa unknown unknown true -180 180 -90 90 Global - http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#MD_CoverageContentTypeCode image AVHRR (vis,IR) European Organisation for the Exploitation of Meteorological Satellites EUMETSAT +49(0)6151-807 3660/3770 +49(0)6151-807 3790 EUMETSAT Allee 1 Darmstadt Hessen 64295 Germany ops@eumetsat.int http://www.eumetsat.int http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/ML_gmxCodelists.xml#MD_ScopeCode distributor distributor https://view.eumetsat.int/productviewer?v=eps:m03_ir108 https View on EUMETView CI_OnLineFunctionCode order View GeoTIFF - Level 1B Product Guide</gco:CharacterString></gmd:name><gmd:function><gmd:CI_OnLineFunctionCode codeList=\"http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_OnLineFunctionCode\" codeListValue=\"information\"/></gmd:function></gmd:CI_OnlineResource></gmd:onlineResource></gmd:CI_Contact></gmd:contactInfo><gmd:role><gmd:CI_RoleCode codeList=\"http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_RoleCode\" codeListValue=\"author\"/></gmd:role></gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty></gmd:citedResponsibleParty><gmd:citedResponsibleParty><gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty><gmd:contactInfo><gmd:CI_Contact><gmd:onlineResource><gmd:CI_OnlineResource><gmd:linkage><gmd:URL>https://www.eumetsat.int/media/38675</gmd:URL></gmd:linkage><gmd:name><gco:CharacterString>AVHRR 3 Level 1 Product Format Specification</gco:CharacterString></gmd:name><gmd:function><gmd:CI_OnLineFunctionCode codeList=\"http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_OnLineFunctionCode\" codeListValue=\"information\"/></gmd:function></gmd:CI_OnlineResource></gmd:onlineResource></gmd:CI_Contact></gmd:contactInfo><gmd:role><gmd:CI_RoleCode codeList=\"http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_RoleCode\" codeListValue=\"author\"/></gmd:role></gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty></gmd:citedResponsibleParty><gmd:citedResponsibleParty><gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty><gmd:contactInfo><gmd:CI_Contact><gmd:onlineResource><gmd:CI_OnlineResource><gmd:linkage><gmd:URL>https://www.eumetsat.int/media/38128</gmd:URL></gmd:linkage><gmd:name><gco:CharacterString>AVHRR L1 Product Generation Specification</gco:CharacterString></gmd:name><gmd:function><gmd:CI_OnLineFunctionCode codeList=\"http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_OnLineFunctionCode\" codeListValue=\"information\"/></gmd:function></gmd:CI_OnlineResource></gmd:onlineResource></gmd:CI_Contact></gmd:contactInfo><gmd:role><gmd:CI_RoleCode codeList=\"http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_RoleCode\" codeListValue=\"author\"/></gmd:role></gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty></gmd:citedResponsibleParty></gmd:CI_Citation></gmd:citation><gmd:abstract><gco:CharacterString>This is an image of Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer (AVHRR) channel IR 10.8 Level 1b Brightness Temperatures, accumulated over the last 6 orbits. The indicated time represents the end of the last orbit (when the satellite crosses the equator in the ascending node). \nThe IR10.8 channel is an atmospheric window channel (where the absorption of the gas molecules is low), and it helps in distinguishing thick clouds by to their cloud top temperatures.  \nThe accumulated images are displayed mapping the same temperature range for day and night, i.e. 220 K-310 K, in order to have quite homogeneous images during the entire 24 hours and also to have a good contrast in the polar regions.\nThe Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer (AVHRR) is a multipurpose imaging instrument used for global monitoring of cloud cover, sea surface temperature, ice, snow and vegetation cover characteristics. It operates at 6 different channels simultaneously at a spatial resolution of about 1 Km near-nadir.\nAVHRR has many applications in oceanography, meteorology and terrestrial sciences:\n- Multi-Channel SST (MCSST) is the main geophysical parameter of use in AVHRR oceanographic applications. \n- Another oceanographic application of AVHRR data is in the study of sea ice. Properly filtered for clouds over ice, AVHRR imagery can be used to compute sea ice concentration, type and ice edge location. It can also be used to compute ice motion.\n- Multi-channel imagery from the AVHRR has also proven to be useful in snow cover mapping. The frequent coverage of the AVHRR is the prime advantage in being able to distinguish clouds from snow cover with their similar albedo signature. Combined with topographic relief information, snow cover from AVHRR can be converted to snow-water equivalent to give an estimate of the amount of water reserve represented by the winter snow pack.\n- Day and night cloud mapping is the main application of AVHRR data in meteorology, especially at high latitudes where data from geostationary satellites are severely affected by Earth curvature. AVHRR's frequent day/night synoptic coverage and high horizontal resolution are features that make the system unique for the study of land surface. </gco:CharacterString></gmd:abstract><gmd:status><gmd:MD_ProgressCode codeList=\"http://navigator.eumetsat.int/metadata_schema/eum/resources/Codelist/eum_gmxCodelists.xml#MD_ProgressCode\" codeListValue=\"Operational\"/></gmd:status><gmd:pointOfContact><gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty><gmd:individualName><gco:CharacterString>European Organisation for the Exploitation of Meteorological Satellites</gco:CharacterString></gmd:individualName><gmd:organisationName><gco:CharacterString>EUMETSAT</gco:CharacterString></gmd:organisationName><gmd:contactInfo><gmd:CI_Contact><gmd:phone><gmd:CI_Telephone><gmd:voice><gco:CharacterString>+49(0)6151-807 3660/3770</gco:CharacterString></gmd:voice><gmd:facsimile><gco:CharacterString>+49(0)6151-807 3790</gco:CharacterString></gmd:facsimile></gmd:CI_Telephone></gmd:phone><gmd:address><gmd:CI_Address><gmd:deliveryPoint><gco:CharacterString>EUMETSAT Allee 1</gco:CharacterString></gmd:deliveryPoint><gmd:city><gco:CharacterString>Darmstadt</gco:CharacterString></gmd:city><gmd:administrativeArea><gco:CharacterString>Hessen</gco:CharacterString></gmd:administrativeArea><gmd:postalCode><gco:CharacterString>64295</gco:CharacterString></gmd:postalCode><gmd:country><gco:CharacterString>Germany</gco:CharacterString></gmd:country><gmd:electronicMailAddress><gco:CharacterString>ops@eumetsat.int</gco:CharacterString></gmd:electronicMailAddress></gmd:CI_Address></gmd:address><gmd:onlineResource><gmd:CI_OnlineResource><gmd:linkage><gmd:URL>http://www.eumetsat.int</gmd:URL></gmd:linkage></gmd:CI_OnlineResource></gmd:onlineResource></gmd:CI_Contact></gmd:contactInfo><gmd:role><gmd:CI_RoleCode codeList=\"http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/ML_gmxCodelists.xml#MD_ScopeCode\" #> [[4]]$`_source`$schemaOrgDefinition
#> [1] "{\"@context\":\"http://schema.org/\",\"@type\":\"Dataset\",\"url\":\"https://navigator.eumetsat.int/product/EO:EUM:DAT:0199\",\"measurementTechnique\":\"Radiometer\",\"copyrightHolder\":{\"@type\":\"Organization\",\"name\":\"EUMETSAT\",\"contactPoint\":{\"@type\":\"ContactPoint\",\"contactType\":\"customer support\",\"telephone\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3660/3770\",\"email\":\"ops@eumetsat.int\",\"url\":\"http://www.eumetsat.int\",\"faxNumber\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3790\"}},\"creator\":{\"@type\":\"Organization\",\"name\":\"EUMETSAT\",\"contactPoint\":{\"@type\":\"ContactPoint\",\"contactType\":\"customer support\",\"telephone\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3660/3770\",\"email\":\"ops@eumetsat.int\",\"url\":\"http://www.eumetsat.int\",\"faxNumber\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3790\"}},\"isAccessibleForFree\":\"false\",\"keywords\":\"Metop,GeoTIFF,Atmosphere,LEO,Ocean,Level 1 Data,Land,Radiometer,AVHRR\",\"license\":\"https://eoportal.eumetsat.int/userMgmt/terms.faces\",\"publisher\":{\"@type\":\"Organization\",\"name\":\"EUMETSAT\",\"contactPoint\":{\"@type\":\"ContactPoint\",\"contactType\":\"customer support\",\"telephone\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3660/3770\",\"email\":\"ops@eumetsat.int\",\"url\":\"http://www.eumetsat.int\",\"faxNumber\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3790\"}},\"schemaVersion\":\"3.5\",\"spatialCoverage\":{\"@type\":\"Place\",\"geo\":{\"@type\":\"GeoShape\",\"polygon\":\"-180.0  90.0  180.0  -90.0\"}},\"thumbnailUrl\":\"https://navigator.eumetsat.int/preview/eps-metop1_ir108_THUMBNAIL_small.jpg\",\"encodingFormat\":\"GeoTIFF\",\"description\":\"This is an image of Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer (AVHRR) channel IR 10.8 Level 1b Brightness Temperatures, accumulated over the last 6 orbits. The indicated time represents the end of the last orbit (when the satellite crosses the equator in the ascending node). \\nThe IR10.8 channel is an atmospheric window channel (where the absorption of the gas molecules is low), and it helps in distinguishing thick clouds by to their cloud top temperatures.  \\nThe accumulated images are displayed mapping the same temperature range for day and night, i.e. 220 K-310 K, in order to have quite homogeneous images during the entire 24 hours and also to have a good contrast in the polar regions.\\nThe Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer (AVHRR) is a multipurpose imaging instrument used for global monitoring of cloud cover, sea surface temperature, ice, snow and vegetation cover characteristics. It operates at 6 different channels simultaneously at a spatial resolution of about 1 Km near-nadir.\\nAVHRR has many applications in oceanography, meteorology and terrestrial sciences:\\n- Multi-Channel SST (MCSST) is the main geophysical parameter of use in AVHRR oceanographic applications. \\n- Another oceanographic application of AVHRR data is in the study of sea ice. Properly filtered for clouds over ice, AVHRR imagery can be used to compute sea ice concentration, type and ice edge location. It can also be used to compute ice motion.\\n- Multi-channel imagery from the AVHRR has also proven to be useful in snow cover mapping. The frequent coverage of the AVHRR is the prime advantage in being able to distinguish clouds from snow cover with their similar albedo signature. Combined with topographic relief information, snow cover from AVHRR can be converted to snow-water equivalent to give an estimate of the amount of water reserve represented by the winter snow pack.\\n- Day and night cloud mapping is the main application of AVHRR data in meteorology, especially at high latitudes where data from geostationary satellites are severely affected by Earth curvature. AVHRR's frequent day/night synoptic coverage and high horizontal resolution are features that make the system unique for the study of land surface. \",\"identifier\":\"EO:EUM:DAT:0199\",\"name\":\"AVHRR IR10.8 6 orbits accumulated - Metop C\"}"
#>

#> 
#> [[5]]$`_source`
#> [[5]]$`_source`$abstract
#> [1] "Single orbital ground tracks of platform METOP-B, for Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer (AVHRR) instrument.\r\nThe product displays the path that the satellite \"draws\" on the surface of Earth while moving in a geosynchronous orbit.\r\nFrom every single orbit it is possible to access to all the Product Dissemination Units (PDUs) included in that orbit.\r\nEach PDU contains 3 minutes of measurements. There are approximately 33/34 PDUs per orbit.\r\nFor every PDU, the starting time is provided, in format YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ssZ."
#>

The product displays the path that the satellite \"draws\" on the surface of Earth while moving in a geosynchronous orbit. From every single orbit it is possible to access to all the Product Dissemination Units (PDUs) included in that orbit. Each PDU contains 3 minutes of measurements. There are approximately 33/34 PDUs per orbit. For every PDU, the starting time is provided, in format YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ssZ. codeListValue=\"author\"/></gmd:role></gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty></gmd:citedResponsibleParty></gmd:CI_Citation></gmd:citation><gmd:abstract><gco:CharacterString>Single orbital ground tracks of platform METOP-B, for Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer (AVHRR) instrument.&#xD;\nThe product displays the path that the satellite \"draws\" on the surface of Earth while moving in a geosynchronous orbit.&#xD;\nFrom every single orbit it is possible to access to all the Product Dissemination Units (PDUs) included in that orbit.&#xD;\nEach PDU contains 3 minutes of measurements. There are approximately 33/34 PDUs per orbit.&#xD;\nFor every PDU, the starting time is provided, in format YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ssZ.</gco:CharacterString></gmd:abstract><gmd:pointOfContact><gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty><gmd:individualName><gco:CharacterString>European Organisation for the Exploitation of codeListValue=\"series\"/></gmd:level></gmd:DQ_Scope></gmd:scope><gmd:lineage><gmd:LI_Lineage><gmd:statement><gco:CharacterString>-</gco:CharacterString></gmd:statement></gmd:LI_Lineage></gmd:lineage></gmd:DQ_DataQuality></gmd:dataQualityInfo><gmi:acquisitionInformation><gmi:MI_AcquisitionInformation><gmi:platform><eum:MI_EUMPlatform><gmi:identifier><gmd:MD_Identifier><gmd:code><gco:CharacterString>Metop</gco:CharacterString></gmd:code></gmd:MD_Identifier></gmi:identifier><gmi:description><gco:CharacterString>Metop</gco:CharacterString></gmi:description><gmi:instrument><eum:MI_EUMInstrument><gmi:citation><gmd:CI_Citation><gmd:title><gco:CharacterString>AVHRR</gco:CharacterString></gmd:title><gmd:date><gmd:CI_Date><gmd:date><gco:Date>2008-06-01</gco:Date></gmd:date><gmd:dateType><gmd:CI_DateTypeCode codeList=\"http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/ISO_19139_Schemas/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_DateTypeCode\" codeListValue=\"creation\"/></gmd:dateType></gmd:CI_Date></gmd:date><gmd:identifier><gmd:MD_Identifier><gmd:code><gco:CharacterString>AVHRR</gco:CharacterString></gmd:code></gmd:MD_Identifier></gmd:identifier></gmd:CI_Citation></gmi:citation><gmi:type><gmi:MI_SensorTypeCode id=\"z415aaa\" uuid=\"z415aaa\"/></gmi:type><eum:type><MI_EUMSensorTypeCode xmlns=\"http://www.eumetsat.int/2008/gmi\" codeList=\"http://navigator.eumetsat.int/metadata_schema/eum/resources/Codelist/eum_gmxCodelists.xml#CI_SensorTypeCode\" #> [[5]]$`_source`$schemaOrgDefinition
#> [1] "{\"@context\":\"http://schema.org/\",\"@type\":\"Dataset\",\"url\":\"https://navigator.eumetsat.int/product/EO:EUM:DAT:0193\",\"measurementTechnique\":\"Radiometer\",\"copyrightHolder\":{\"@type\":\"Organization\",\"name\":\"EUMETSAT\",\"contactPoint\":{\"@type\":\"ContactPoint\",\"contactType\":\"customer support\",\"telephone\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3660/3770\",\"email\":\"ops@eumetsat.int\",\"url\":\"http://www.eumetsat.int\",\"faxNumber\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3790\"}},\"creator\":{\"@type\":\"Organization\",\"name\":\"EUMETSAT\",\"contactPoint\":{\"@type\":\"ContactPoint\",\"contactType\":\"customer support\",\"telephone\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3660/3770\",\"email\":\"ops@eumetsat.int\",\"url\":\"http://www.eumetsat.int\",\"faxNumber\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3790\"}},\"isAccessibleForFree\":\"false\",\"keywords\":\"Metop,LEO,Cloud,Shapefile,Radiometer,AVHRR\",\"license\":\"https://eoportal.eumetsat.int/userMgmt/terms.faces\",\"publisher\":{\"@type\":\"Organization\",\"name\":\"EUMETSAT\",\"contactPoint\":{\"@type\":\"ContactPoint\",\"contactType\":\"customer support\",\"telephone\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3660/3770\",\"email\":\"ops@eumetsat.int\",\"url\":\"http://www.eumetsat.int\",\"faxNumber\":\"+49(0)6151-807 3790\"}},\"schemaVersion\":\"3.5\",\"spatialCoverage\":{\"@type\":\"Place\",\"geo\":{\"@type\":\"GeoShape\",\"polygon\":\"-180.0  90.0  180.0  -90.0\"}},\"thumbnailUrl\":\"https://vnavigator.eumetsat.int/preview/OrbitTracks.jpg\",\"encodingFormat\":\"Shapefile\",\"description\":\"Single orbital ground tracks of platform METOP-B, for Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer (AVHRR) instrument.\\r\\nThe product displays the path that the satellite \\\"draws\\\" on the surface of Earth while moving in a geosynchronous orbit.\\r\\nFrom every single orbit it is possible to access to all the Product Dissemination Units (PDUs) included in that orbit.\\r\\nEach PDU contains 3 minutes of measurements. There are approximately 33/34 PDUs per orbit.\\r\\nFor every PDU, the starting time is provided, in format YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ssZ.\",\"identifier\":\"EO:EUM:DAT:0193\",\"name\":\"Orbital Ground Tracks - Metop B\"}"
#>

#> [[6]]$`_ignored`
#> [[6]]$`_ignored`[[1]]
#> [1] "dateStamp"
#> 
#> 
#> [[6]]$`_source`
#> [[6]]$`_source`$abstract
#> [1] "Rectified (level 1.5) Meteosat SEVIRI image data. The data is transmitted as High Rate transmissions in 12 spectral channels. Level 1.5 image data corresponds to the geolocated and radiometrically pre-processed image data, ready for further processing, e.g. the extraction of meteorological products. Any spacecraft specific effects have been removed, and in particular, linearisation and equalisation of the image radiometry has been performed for all SEVIRI channels. The on-board blackbody data has been processed. Both radiometric and geometric quality control information is included."

image data. The data is transmitted as High Rate transmissions in 12 spectral channels. Level 1.5 image data corresponds to the geolocated and radiometrically pre-processed image data, ready for further processing, e.g. the extraction of meteorological products. Any spacecraft specific effects have been removed, and in particular, linearisation and equalisation of the image radiometry has been performed for all SEVIRI channels. The on-board blackbody data has been processed. Both radiometric and geometric quality control information is included.</gco:CharacterString></gmd:abstract><gmd:status><gmd:MD_ProgressCode The data is transmitted as High Rate transmissions in 12 spectral channels. Level 1.5 image data corresponds to the geolocated and radiometrically pre-processed image data, ready for further processing, e.g. the extraction of meteorological products. Any spacecraft specific effects have been removed, and in particular, linearisation and equalisation of the image radiometry has been performed for all SEVIRI channels. The on-board blackbody data has been processed. #> [[7]]
#> [[7]]$`_index`
#> [1] "csw"
#> 
#> [[7]]$`_type`
#> [1] "record"
